item.title: Singapore’s Wong Unveils New Cabinet, Keeps Finance Minister Job
item.description: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong unveiled his new cabinet Wednesday, opting to retain his role as finance minister following a convincing electoral victory earlier this month, CNA reported.
item.dc:creator: Faris Mokhtar, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Lawrence Wong

item.title: Israel Faces Global Isolation Over War on Gaza
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: Israeli military vehicles at Israel's southern border with the Gaza Strip on May 20. Photographer: JACK GUEZ/AFP

item.title: EU Unveils Plan to Reinvigorate World’s Second-Biggest Market
item.description: The European Union is seeking to strengthen its common market in the face of rising geopolitical tensions and a growing trade conflict with the US, which is threatening to hit the bloc with wide-ranging tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen on May 21.

item.title: Trump Import-Tax Hike Counters Income-Tax Relief, Economists Say
item.description: The rapidly evolving outlook for US economic growth is boiling down to a tale of two tax policies.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: Trucks cross the Vincent Thomas Bridge at the Port of Los Angeles in San Pedro, California.

item.title: Congress Pulls Tax Cut All-Nighter With SALT Fight Unresolved
item.description: House lawmakers debated the contours of President Donald Trump’s tax cuts throughout the night as they race to meet a self-imposed deadline to approve the legislation by Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Representative Virginia Foxx presides over a Rules Committee meeting at the US Capitol, on May 21.

item.title: BYD Documents Sought by House Panel in Probe of US Electric Bus Unit
item.description: Chinese automaker and Apple Inc supplier BYD is being asked to turn over its books to the House Homeland Security Committee, as part of an investigation into national security risks posed by transportation manufacturers affiliated with the ruling Chinese Communist Party, the committee told Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: The BYD electric bus factory in Lancaster, California.

item.title: Germany Makes Arrests of Suspected Right-Wing Terrorist Cell
item.description: Germany arrested five people accused of participating in a right-wing terror cell that sought to attack migrants and undermine the country’s democratic system.
item.dc:creator: Chris Reiter, Karin Matussek

media:content.media:description: Police made arrests in Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, and Hesse, Germany.

item.title: Trump Says Golden Dome Will Be Operational in Three Years
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed that a “Golden Dome” missile-defense shield should be “fully operational” by the end of his term, saying it would be able to protect the US from threats including ballistic missiles, hypersonics and advanced cruise missiles.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 12: White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles looks on from behind a chart on the Golden Dome missile defense system as U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during a press conference in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on May 12, 2025, in Washington, DC. During the event, President Trump signed an executive order aimed at reducing the cost of prescription drugs and pharmaceuticals by 30% to 80%. (Photo by Andrew Harnik/Getty Images)

item.title: Orban’s Plan to Muzzle Dissent Threatens Rule of Law, Judges Say
item.description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s planned crackdown against civil society and media infringes on the rule of law, according to an independent group of judges.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban

item.title: US-China Tensions Over Chips Risk Hurting Trade Truce, Dialogue
item.description: US-China tech tensions are flaring again, with Beijing threatening legal action against anyone enforcing Washington’s restrictions on Huawei Technologies Co.’s chips, casting a shadow over a recent trade truce and efforts to sustain dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. chip

item.title: Japan’s Farm Minister Quits Over Rice Gaffe in Blow to Ishiba
item.description: Japan’s farm minister quit Wednesday after saying he’s never needed to buy rice, a comment that fueled criticism of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s minority government and its handling of rising food prices ahead of an election.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Taku Eto, center, at the parliament in Tokyo on May 19.

item.title: Pakistan Names First Field Marshal in 60 Years After India Clash
item.description: Pakistan promoted its army chief to field marshal for the first time in over sixty years, citing the country’s ‘success’ in this month’s military confrontation with India.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Khalid Qayum

media:content.media:description: A man carries a portrait of Pakistani Army Chief General Syed Asim Munir, during a rally to express solidarity with Pakistan's armed forces, in Islamabad on May 14, 2025.

item.title: French Prosecutors Claim Najib Had Role in 2002 Submarine Deal Bribes
item.description: Allegations against former Malaysian prime minister are in 2024 court document. Prosecutors haven’t recommended that Najib stands trial.
item.dc:creator: Tom Redmond, Niki Koswanage, Jin Wu

media:content.media:description: One of Malaysia’s Scorpene-class submarines, KD Tunku Abdul Rahman, arrives at Pulau Indah Naval Base, in September 2009.

item.title: Chinese Authorities Question Metals Bosses in Smuggling Probe
item.description: Chinese authorities have questioned the heads of some of the country’s leading metals merchants and producers as part of an intensifying effort to crack down on critical-minerals smuggling, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Alfred Cang

item.title: Trump’s Genocide Claim Rakes Up South Africa’s Apartheid Past
item.description: The US president’s offer of refugee status for Afrikaners comes as his administration slashes spending that was helping Black South Africans.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff, Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: The annual Nampo Harvest Day agricultural show near Bothaville, South Africa, on May 14.

item.title: Historic Fall in UK Migration Can’t Come Fast Enough for Starmer
item.description: Figures due on Thursday are likely to show Keir Starmer presiding over the biggest ever drop in net migration to the UK. For the prime minister, however, the hard part will be getting any credit from voters.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Inflatable dinghies and outboard motors believed to have been used by illegal migrants to cross the English channel to England, in Dover. Photographer: Carl Court/Getty Images Europe

item.title: EU Sanctions Ships That Moved LNG From Russia’s Yamal Plant
item.description: The European Union imposed sanctions on three vessels that helped move gas cargoes from Russia’s Yamal LNG project, further squeezing Moscow’s energy revenues.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: A gas flare, also known as a flare stack, burns at the Yamal LNG plant, operated by Novatek PJSC, in Sabetta, Russia, on Wednesday, Aug. 8, 2018. Novatek is one of the largest independent natural gas producers in Russia.

item.title: US Deports Migrants to War-Torn South Sudan, Court Records Say
item.description: A federal judge in Boston has ordered the Trump administration to “maintain custody” of a group of migrant men who may have been deported to South Sudan on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 6: An ICE agent monitors hundreds of asylum seekers being processed upon entering the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building on June 6, 2023 in New York City. New York City has provided sanctuary to over 46,000 asylum seekers since 2013, when the city passed a law prohibiting city agencies from cooperating with federal immigration enforcement agencies unless there is a warrant for the person's arrest.(Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images) Photographer: David Dee Delgado/Getty Images North America

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China Threatens Enforcers of US’s Huawei Curbs With Legal Action
item.description: China said it could take legal action against anyone enforcing US restrictions on using Huawei Technologies Co.’s AI chips, escalating a dispute that’s upset a tentative truce on tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: (Photo by Joan Cros/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Photographer: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Trump Loses Patience With SALT Demand as Tax Bill Faces Snag
item.description: President Donald Trump is growing frustrated with demands to significantly boost the cap on the state and local tax deduction, according to a senior administration official, signaling a deadlock as Republicans aim to quickly pass a giant tax-cut bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Catherine Lucey, Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: FAA Cuts Newark Flights After Air Traffic Control Issues
item.description: US aviation safety regulators will allow fewer flights at Newark airport after technology outages and a staffing crunch fueled a surge in delays and cancellations in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille, Mary Schlangenstein

media:content.media:description: A FAA Air Traffic Control tower and the Newark Liberty International Airport Marriott at Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) in Newark, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Air traffic controllers guiding planes bound for Newark Liberty International Airport lost radar and radio communication for more than a minute early last week before flights at the key hub were snarled for days, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: US, Philippine Coast Guards Join Navy Drills Amid China Tensions
item.description: The US and the Philippines held a new round of joint sails within Manila’s exclusive economic zone, with their coast guards participating for the first time, amid continuing tensions in the disputed South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Manolo Serapio Jr

media:content.media:description: Photo by Ezra Acayan/Getty Images) Photographer: Ezra Acayan/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Chicago Suburb Plans to Seize Pope Leo’s Childhood Home
item.description: A Chicago-area town plans to seize control of Pope Leo XIV’s childhood home, just days after the current owner put the property up for auction.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: The pope’s childhood home in Dolton, Illinois

item.title: Reeves to Meet Bessent as Questions Linger Over UK-US Deal
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will hold talks with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent this week, as the two countries continue to finalize the details of an agreement to cut tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves Photographer: Darren Staples/Getty Images

item.title: Bloody Murders in Quiet Neighborhood Shatter Mexico City’s Calm
item.description: In the vast swaths of Mexico controlled by drug cartels, public executions and mass graves have long been the norm. Mexico City has largely been a haven from the goriest headlines.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Navarro, Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Forensic investigators at the crime scene in Mexico city on May 20.

item.title: Trump Says Golden Dome Will Be Operational in Three Years
item.description: President Donald Trump vowed that a “Golden Dome” missile-defense shield would be “fully operational” by the end of his term, and offer the US protection from an array of threats — even though some of the technology remains unproven.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY

item.title: Mexico City Mayor’s Aides Shot Dead by Attackers on Motorbikes
item.description: Two senior aides to Mexico City Mayor Clara Brugada were shot dead Tuesday in the highest-profile political violence to strike the Latin American metropolis since cartel gunmen ambushed the capital’s former police chief five years ago.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Millan, Andrea Navarro

media:content.media:description: Forensic investigators work at the crime scene of the killing of Jose Munoz and Ximena Guzman in Mexico City on May 20, 2025.

item.title: South Africa’s Budget Gets Third Reboot With Credibility on Line
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana’s third attempt to deliver a budget represents his sternest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, center, speaks to the press after presenting the revised 2025 Budget at the National Assembly in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Godongwana and his National Treasury officials were sent back to the drawing board last month after his revenue and spending plan failed to get buy-in from parties.

item.title: US Clears Way for Tariffs on $13 Billion of Solar Imports
item.description: US duties on solar equipment from four Southeast Asian countries are set to take effect following a government agency’s conclusion the imports harm domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Mark Chediak, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: A worker handles photovoltaic cells at Irex Energy JSC's manufacturing facility in Vung Tau, Vietnam, on Monday, July 15, 2019. After U.S. President Donald Trump slapped higher tariffs on China, production in neighboring Vietnam went into overdrive. Chinese manufacturers, who face a 55% U.S. tariff on their goods, relocated some production to Vietnam, while local businesses saw a jump in orders. In June alone, U.S. imports of solar cells from Vietnam surged 656% from a year ago.
